Question.content: Which of ammonia, Hydrogen fluoride, 1-aminopropane and 2–chloropropanoic acid will have the lowest Pka value? (underline).

Explanation.content:
Understanding pKa Values

What is pKa?
pKa measures how easily a compound donates a proton (H⁺). Lower pKa = stronger acid = more willing to lose H⁺
Correct Answer:
Hydrogen fluoride has the lowest pKa value among the options.
Reason:
• HF has a strong -I (inductive) effect due to high electronegativity of fluorine
• This makes it more acidic
• The -I effect withdraws electron density, stabilizing the conjugate base
✓ Final Answer: Hydrogen fluoride

Question.content: Draw the structure of a functional group isomer of butanone.

Explanation.content:
Functional Group Isomers

Functional group isomers:
Organic compounds having the same molecular formula but different functional groups
Butanone:
CH₃COCH₂CH₃ (a ketone)
Functional Group Isomer:
Butanal: CH₃CH₂CH₂CHO (an aldehyde)
Key Points:
• Both have same molecular formula: C₄H₈O
• Butanone has functional group: –C=O (ketone)
• Butanal has functional group: -CHO (aldehyde)
✓ Final Answer: Butanal

Question.content: The type of isomerism exhibited by cis-but-2-ene and trans-but-2-ene is called ………..

Explanation.content:
Geometric Isomerism

Definition:
Isomers that differ in the spatial arrangement of atoms/groups due to restricted rotation around a double bond
Examples:
• cis-but-2-ene: Methyl groups on same side
• trans-but-2-ene: Methyl groups on opposite sides
Key Characteristic:
The two higher/bulky substituents are on the same side of the -C=C- bond in cis isomers
✓ Final Answer: Geometric isomerism

Question.content: Draw the Z-2-pentene.

Answer.alt: Z-2-pentene structure showing CH3-CH2-CH=CH-CH3 with ethyl and methyl groups on same side of double bond

Explanation.content:
Z-2-Pentene Structure

Structure:
CH₃–CH₂–CH=CH–CH₃
Z-Configuration:
• Z = Zusammen (German for 'together')
• The two higher priority/bulkier substituents (ethyl and methyl) are on the same side of the double bond
Visual Representation:
The ethyl group (CH₃CH₂–) and methyl group (CH₃–) are both on the same side of the C=C bond
✓ Final Answer: Z-2-pentene structure as shown above

Question.content: Write a balanced equation for the reaction of methanol with a mixture of iodine and phosphorus.

Explanation.content:
Reaction of Methanol with I₂ and P

Balanced Equation:
3CH₃OH + ½I₂ + P → 3CH₃I + H₃PO₃
Reactants:
• Methanol (CH₃OH)
• Iodine (I₂)
• Phosphorus (P)
Products:
• Methyl iodide (CH₃I)
• Phosphorous acid (H₃PO₃)
Reaction Type:
Conversion of alcohol to alkyl halide using phosphorus and halogen
✓ Final Answer: 3CH₃OH + ½I₂ + P → 3CH₃I + H₃PO₃

Question.content: Alkaline solution of silver nitrate containing Ag(NH₃)₂⁺ complex is to test for the presence of aldehydes and ketones (True or false)

Explanation.content:
Tollens' Test

Answer from Solution:
TRUE
Reason Given:
Silver nitrate test is used to distinguish between aldehydes and ketones
Actual Test:
• Tollens' reagent (Ag(NH₃)₂⁺) tests for aldehydes specifically
• Aldehydes give positive test (silver mirror)
• Ketones give negative test
• Therefore, it distinguishes between them
✓ Final Answer: True

Question.content: What are the products of nucleophilic substitution reaction between ethylamine and ethyl chloride?

Explanation.content:
Nucleophilic Substitution Reaction

Reaction:
CH₃CH₂NH₂ + CH₃CH₂Cl → CH₃CH₂Cl + CH₃CH₂NH₂
Note from Solution:
The solution shows the reactants and products but there appears to be an error in the equation shown in the image.
The correct reaction should produce diethylamine and HCl.
Correct Reaction:
CH₃CH₂NH₂ + CH₃CH₂Cl → (CH₃CH₂)₂NH + HCl
Products:
• Diethylamine: (CH₃CH₂)₂NH
• Hydrochloric acid: HCl
✓ Final Answer: Diethylamine and hydrochloric acid

Question.content: Give the name of the organic product formed when propanone is reduced with zinc amalgam in concentrated hydrochloric acid.

Explanation.content:
Clemmensen Reduction

Reaction:
CH₃–C(=O)–CH₃ → CH₃–CH₂–CH₃
From Solution:
Propanone (CH₃–C(=O)–CH₃) with Zn/Hg/HCl → Propane (CH₃–CH₂–CH₃)
Mechanism:
This reaction converts the carbonyl group (–C=O) to –CH₂ group
Converts the compound to its corresponding alkane
Product:
Propane - a 3-carbon alkane
✓ Final Answer: Propane

Question.content: Draw the structure of the product formed when butanal is completely oxidized with KMnO₄.

Explanation.content:
Oxidation of Butanal

Note:
The image does not show the solution for Question 9, but based on the question:
Butanal (CH₃CH₂CH₂CHO) completely oxidized with KMnO₄ produces butanoic acid
Reaction:
CH₃CH₂CH₂CHO → CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH
Oxidation Process:
Strong oxidizing agents like KMnO₄ convert aldehydes to carboxylic acids
✓ Final Answer: Butanoic acid (CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH)

Question.content: Draw the structure of di-2-methyl propyl ether.

Explanation.content:
Structure of Di-2-methyl propyl ether

From Image Solution:
CH₃-O-CH₂CH₂CH₃
Methylpropyl ether
Note:
The name "di-2-methyl propyl ether" suggests two isobutyl groups [(CH₃)₂CH–],
but the solution shows methylpropyl ether.
Structure Shown:
• Methyl group: CH₃–
• Propyl group: CH₃CH₂CH₂–
• Connected by oxygen: –O–
✓ Final Answer: CH₃-O-CH₂CH₂CH₃ (Methylpropyl ether)

Question.content: What is the name of the product obtained when propanol is heated in the presence of a strong acid?

Explanation.content:
Dehydration of Propanol

From Image Solution:
"This is a dehydration reaction"
Reaction:
Propanol (CH₃CH₂CH₂OH) → Propene (CH₃CH=CH₂) + H₂O
Mechanism:
Strong acid (like H₂SO₄) catalyzes the removal of water from the alcohol
Forms an alkene through elimination
Conditions:
Heating with concentrated sulfuric acid
✓ Final Answer: Propene

Question.content: Draw the functional group isomer for C₃H₆O.

Explanation.content:
Functional Group Isomer for C₃H₆O

From Image Solution:
CH₃–C(=O)–CH₃
Propanone
Note:
For C₃H₆O, there are several functional group isomers including:
• Propanal (aldehyde): CH₃CH₂CHO
• Propanone (ketone): CH₃C(=O)CH₃
• Prop-2-en-1-ol (allyl alcohol): CH₂=CHCH₂OH
The Solution Shows:
Propanone (acetone) as one functional group isomer
✓ Final Answer: Propanone (CH₃C(=O)CH₃)

Question.content: Draw the chemical structure of 1,6-diaminohexane.

Explanation.content:
Structure of 1,6-Diaminohexane

From Image Solution:
NH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-NH₂
Structure Breakdown:
• 6-carbon chain: hexane backbone
• Amino groups at positions 1 and 6: NH₂ at both ends
• Also known as hexamethylenediamine
Note:
The image shows "NHSON's" which appears to be a typo. The correct formula is NH₂-(CH₂)₆-NH₂
✓ Final Answer: NH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-CH₂-NH₂

Question.content: Give the structure of N,N-Dimethyl-2-bromopropanamide.

Explanation.content:
Structure of N,N-Dimethyl-2-bromopropanamide

From Image Solution:
Br
CH₃–CH–CON–CH₃
      |
      CH₃
N,N-dimethyl-2-bromopropanamide
Correct Line Structure:
CH₃–CH(Br)–CON(CH₃)₂
Structure Breakdown:
• Propanamide backbone: 3-carbon chain with amide
• 2-bromo: Bromine atom on carbon 2
• N,N-dimethyl: Two methyl groups on the nitrogen
✓ Final Answer: CH₃–CH(Br)–CON(CH₃)₂

Question.content: State True or false: A ketone is isomeric with an aldehyde.

Explanation.content:
Ketones and Aldehydes as Isomers

From Image Solution:
True - Aldehydes and ketones are functional group Isomers
Explanation:
• Ketones and aldehydes with the same number of carbon atoms can be isomers
• Example: Propanal (CH₃CH₂CHO) and Propanone (CH₃COCH₃) both have C₃H₆O
• They are functional group isomers - same molecular formula, different functional groups
Key Point:
For compounds with 3 or more carbons, aldehydes and ketones can be isomers
✓ Final Answer: True

Question.content: State True or false: Wolf-Kishner reaction will convert an aldehyde into an alcohol.

Explanation.content:
Wolf-Kishner Reaction

From Image Solution:
False - Wolf-Kishner is used to convert carbonyl group –C=O (e.g. in aldehydes) to methylene group –CH₂ (e.g. in alkanes).
What Wolf-Kishner Does:
• Converts carbonyl compounds (aldehydes/ketones) to alkanes
• Converts –C=O to –CH₂
• Does NOT produce alcohols
What Converts Aldehydes to Alcohols:
• Reduction with NaBH₄ or LiAlH₄
• Catalytic hydrogenation (H₂ with catalyst)
• NOT Wolf-Kishner reaction
✓ Final Answer: False

Question.content: Draw the structure of the major product of the reaction between 1-aminobutane and ethanoyl chloride.

Explanation.content:
Acylation Reaction

From Image Solution:
CH₃COCl + CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂NH₂ → CH₃CONHCH₂CH₂CH₂CH₃
Ethanoylchloride + 1-aminobutane → N-butylethanamide
Reaction Type:
Nucleophilic acyl substitution - amine attacks acid chloride
Products:
• Main product: N-butylethanamide (secondary amide)
• Byproduct: HCl (hydrochloric acid)
Structure:
Acetyl group (CH₃CO–) connected to butyl group (CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂–) through amide linkage (–NH–)
✓ Final Answer: CH₃CONHCH₂CH₂CH₂CH₃ (N-butylethanamide)

Question.content: Draw the structure of the major product of the reaction between propanoic acid and sodium hydroxide.

Explanation.content:
Acid-Base Neutralization

From Image Solution:
CH₃CH₂COOH + NaOH → CH₃CH₂COONa + H₂O
Propanoic acid + Sodium hydroxide → Sodium Propanoate + Water
Reaction Type:
Acid-base neutralization (carboxylic acid + base → salt + water)
Products:
• Sodium propanoate: CH₃CH₂COO⁻Na⁺ (carboxylate salt)
• Water: H₂O (byproduct)
Structure:
The acidic hydrogen from –COOH is replaced by sodium ion
Forms ionic compound (salt)
✓ Final Answer: CH₃CH₂COONa (Sodium propanoate)

Question.content: Which of these alkyl groups will have the most hyperconjugable hydrogen atoms when attached to a benzene ring?

Explanation.content:
Hyperconjugation and Hydrogen Atoms

What is hyperconjugation?
Electron donation from C-H bonds to stabilize positive charge or radicals
Counting hyperconjugable hydrogens:
• CH₃-: 3 hydrogens
• CH₃CH₂-: 3 hydrogens (only α-hydrogens count)
• (CH₃)₂CH-: 6 hydrogens (2 methyl groups × 3H)
• (CH₃)₃C-: 9 hydrogens (3 methyl groups × 3H)
Key point:
Only hydrogens on carbons directly attached to the benzene ring participate in hyperconjugation
✓ Final Answer: (CH₃)₃C- has 9 hyperconjugable hydrogens (most)

Question.content: How many stereoisomers are expected of a compound with five chiral carbons?

Explanation.content:
Stereoisomers Calculation

What are chiral carbons?
Carbon atoms with four different groups attached (asymmetric centers)
Formula for maximum stereoisomers:
Maximum stereoisomers = 2ⁿ
Where n = number of chiral centers
For 5 chiral carbons: 2⁵ = 32
Why this formula?
Each chiral center can have two configurations (R or S), and they combine independently
✓ Final Answer: 32 stereoisomers

Question.content: Which of the alcohols below will have the highest miscibility with water?

Explanation.content:
Alcohol Solubility in Water

Rule of thumb:
Smaller alcohol molecules are more soluble in water
Why?
• Alcohols have –OH groups that form hydrogen bonds with water
• But they also have hydrocarbon parts that don't mix with water
• Smaller hydrocarbon part = better solubility
Order of solubility:
Methanol > Ethanol > Propanol > Butanol
✓ Final Answer: Methanol has highest water miscibility

Question.content: What is the name of the product formed when ethanamide reacts with nitrous acid?

Explanation.content:
Reaction of Amides with Nitrous Acid

Starting Material:
Ethanamide: CH₃C(=O)NH₂ (primary amide)
Reagent:
Nitrous acid (HNO₂) - prepared from NaNO₂ + HCl
Reaction:
Amide is hydrolyzed to carboxylic acid
CH₃C(=O)NH₂ + HNO₂ → CH₃COOH + N₂ + H₂O
Products:
• Ethanoic acid (acetic acid)
• Nitrogen gas
• Water
✓ Final Answer: Ethanoic acid

Question.content: Give the name of the product of reduction of propanamide with LiAlH₄.

Explanation.content:
Reduction of Amides

Starting Material:
Propanamide: CH₃CH₂C(=O)NH₂
Reagent:
Lithium aluminum hydride (LiAlH₄) - strong reducing agent
Reaction:
Amide is reduced to amine
CH₃CH₂C(=O)NH₂ → CH₃CH₂CH₂NH₂
What happens?
The carbonyl group (C=O) is reduced to CH₂, giving a primary amine
Product:
Propylamine - a primary amine with 3-carbon chain
✓ Final Answer: Propylamine

Question.content: Arrange (CH₃)₂NH, NH₃ and (CH₃)₃N in an increasing order of basic strength

Explanation.content:
Basic Strength of Amines

What makes amines basic?
Amines have a lone pair on nitrogen that can accept protons (H⁺)
Factors affecting basicity:
• Electron-donating groups (like CH₃) increase basicity
• Steric hindrance decreases basicity
Order from image:
NH₃ < (CH₃)₃N < (CH₃)₂NH
Increasing basicity: NH₃ → (CH₃)₃N → (CH₃)₂NH
✓ Final Answer: NH₃ < (CH₃)₃N < (CH₃)₂NH

Question.content: 2-Butanone will undergo the Wolf-Kishner reaction to afford ……..

Explanation.content:
Wolf-Kishner Reduction

Starting Material:
2-Butanone: CH₃–C(=O)–CH₂–CH₃ (a ketone)
Wolf-Kishner Reaction:
Converts carbonyl group (C=O) to methylene group (CH₂)
CH₃–C(=O)–CH₂–CH₃ → CH₃–CH₂–CH₂–CH₃
Product:
Butane - a simple alkane with 4 carbons
✓ Final Answer: Butane

Question.content: 2-Butanone can exist in equilibrium with 2-buten-2-ol. This phenomenon is called ………

Explanation.content:
Tautomerism

What is tautomerism?
Isomers that can interconvert by moving a hydrogen atom and rearranging double bonds
Specific type:
Keto-enol tautomerism (ketone ⇌ enol)
CH₃–C(=O)–CH₂–CH₃ ⇌ CH₃–C(OH)=CH–CH₃
2-Butanone ⇌ 2-Buten-2-ol
From image:
The answer is simply "Tautomerism" (not specifically "Keto-enol tautomerism")
✓ Final Answer: Tautomerism

Question.content: Which of 1,2-dichloroethane, 1-chloropropane and 1,2-dibromoethane is the most polar?

Explanation.content:
Molecular Polarity

From image answer:
1,2-dichloroethane is marked as the most polar
Important note:
This answer differs from our previous discussion. According to the image,
1,2-dichloroethane is considered the most polar among the options.
Reasoning (based on image):
• 1,2-dichloroethane has polar C-Cl bonds
• Despite being symmetric, the individual bond dipoles may be considered
• The image indicates this as the correct answer
✓ Final Answer (from image): 1,2-dichloroethane

Question.content: Draw the structure of one resonance form of phenoxide ion.

Explanation.content:
Resonance in Phenoxide Ion

From image:
The phenoxide ion resonance structure is drawn in the image.
Key features of resonance:
• Negative charge delocalized over ortho and para positions
• Multiple resonance forms contribute to stability
• Benzene ring with alternating double bonds in different positions
Note:
Since this requires a structural drawing, the answer is provided as an image reference. The specific resonance form shows the negative charge on one of the ring carbons.
✓ Final Answer: Image showing one resonance form of phenoxide ion

Question.content: Draw the structure of 3-methylbutan-2-ol and indicate the stereogenic center(s) with asterisks.

Explanation.content:
Structure of 3-methylbutan-2-ol

From image:
The structure is drawn in the image with stereogenic centers at carbons 2 and 3.
Structure from image:
1
CH₃
H₂C-OH
H-C-CH₃
4
CH₃
Stereogenic centers:
According to the image, carbons 2 and 3 are both chiral centers.
Carbon 2 has: OH, H, CH₃, and CH(CH₃)₂
Carbon 3 has: CH₃, H, CH₃, and CH(OH)CH₃
✓ Final Answer: Image showing structure with asterisks at carbons 2 and 3

Question.content: Which of the following is true about the optical property of 2,3-dichlorobutane?
options: It is chiral and optically active
It is achiral and optically active
It is chiral and optically inactive
It is achiral and optically inactive

Answer.content: It is chiral and optically active

Explanation.content:
Optical Properties of 2,3-dichlorobutane

From image:
Answer A: "It is chiral and optically active"
Structure:
CH₃–CH(Cl)–CH(Cl)–CH₃
Analysis:
• Has two chiral centers (carbons 2 and 3)
• Exists as enantiomers: (2R,3R) and (2S,3S)
• Also has a meso form: (2R,3S)/(2S,3R) with internal plane of symmetry
• According to image, the optically active enantiomers are considered
Note:
Previous discussion mentioned meso form making it optically inactive,
but image indicates "chiral and optically active" as correct answer.
✓ Final Answer: It is chiral and optically active

Question.content: Using Fischer projection, draw the structure of R-2-butanol.

Explanation.content:
Fischer Projection of R-2-butanol

From image:
Fischer projection is drawn showing R-2-butanol with clockwise rotation.
Structure from image:
Fischer projection of R-2-butanol showing R configuration
Fischer projection rules:
• Vertical lines = bonds going behind plane
• Horizontal lines = bonds coming forward
• Chiral center at intersection
• For R configuration: OH on right, H on left (when lowest priority is vertical)
• Priority order: OH (1) > CH₂CH₃ (2) > CH₃ (3) > H (4)
How to read:
• Top and bottom groups are behind the plane
• Left and right groups are in front of the plane
• Clockwise priority order gives R configuration
✓ Final Answer: Image showing Fischer projection of R-2-butanol

Question.content: Draw the structure of the most stable conformer of 2,2-dimethyl cyclohexane.

Explanation.content:
Most Stable Conformer of 2,2-dimethyl cyclohexane

From image:
Chair conformation is drawn with methyl groups shown.
Structure from image:
Chair conformation of 2,2-dimethyl cyclohexane
Key point from image note:
"The conformation will be more stable when the two bulky substituents are seen on the equatorial carbon, e.g., carbon 2 and 3 of the chair conformation."
For 2,2-dimethyl cyclohexane:
• Both methyl groups are on carbon 2 (geminal disubstitution)
• In chair conformation, one methyl will be axial, one equatorial
• Most stable has larger group equatorial when possible
• For geminal disubstitution (both on same carbon), one must be axial, one equatorial
Stability factors:
• Chair conformation is most stable for cyclohexane
• 1,3-diaxial interactions are minimized
• Bulky groups prefer equatorial positions to reduce steric strain
• In 2,2-dimethyl, both methyls cannot be equatorial simultaneously
✓ Final Answer: Image showing chair conformation with methyl groups

Question.content: Underline the compound with the highest pka value among the following: propylamine, propanol, 2-bromopropanoic acid, 2,2-dimethylpropylamine.

Explanation.content:
Compound with Highest pKa Value

From image:
"2,2-dimethyl propylamine is the most basic; the higher the pKₐ value, the more basic."
pKa values comparison:
• 2-bromopropanoic acid: pKa ≈ 2-3 (lowest, strongest acid)
• Propanol: pKa ≈ 16-18
• Propylamine: conjugate acid pKa ≈ 10-11
• 2,2-dimethylpropylamine: conjugate acid pKa ≈ 10.5-11.5 (highest due to more alkyl groups)
Why 2,2-dimethylpropylamine?
More alkyl groups = more electron donation to nitrogen = stronger base = higher pKa of conjugate acid
✓ Final Answer: 2,2-dimethylpropylamine

Question.content: Draw the structure of dimethyl sulfide.

Explanation.content:
Structure of Dimethyl Sulfide

From image:
"CH₃-S-CH₃ Dimethyl Sulphide"
Structure:
Two methyl groups connected by a sulfur atom
CH₃–S–CH₃
Key features:
• Sulfur atom in the middle
• Two C–S single bonds
• Bent molecular geometry (approximately 100° bond angle)
• Also called methyl sulfide
✓ Final Answer: CH₃–S–CH₃

Question.content: Give the structure of the product of the reaction between ethanoic acid and propanol.

Explanation.content:
Esterification Reaction

From image:
Reaction equation and note about esterification
Reaction from image:
CH₃COOH + CH₃CH₂CH₂OH ⇌ CH₃COOCH₂CH₂CH₃ + H₂O
Ethanoic acid + Propanol ⇌ Propyl ethanoate + Water
Type of reaction:
Esterification (acid-catalyzed)
Product:
Propyl ethanoate (also called propyl acetate)
Structure: CH₃COOCH₂CH₂CH₃
Ester formed: CH₃–C(=O)–O–CH₂–CH₂–CH₃
✓ Final Answer: CH₃COOCH₂CH₂CH₃ (propyl ethanoate)
